name: Our Local Area
subject: Geography
curriculum_reference: NC KS1 Geography: 'understand geographical similarities and differences through studying the human and physical geography of a small area of the United Kingdom, and of a small area in a contrasting non-European country'
pedagogical_rationale: The local area study is the starting point for geographical enquiry at KS1, grounding abstract concepts in direct experience. Pupils observe, describe, and map the human and physical features of their immediate environment, building the observational and descriptive vocabulary that underpins all subsequent geography. The school determines which local area to study, making this universally relevant.
common_pitfalls: Treating the local study as a one-off activity rather than returning to it throughout the year as new concepts are learned
Focusing only on human features (buildings, shops) and neglecting physical features (rivers, hills, vegetation) in the local area
Not connecting the local study to the contrasting non-European locality — the two should be taught in dialogue
cross_curricular_hooks: [Science] Seasonal changes observed in the local environment
[Maths] Simple data collection — counting types of buildings, shops, or vehicles
[Art] Sketching local landmarks and physical features
[History] How the local area has changed within living memory
fieldwork_potential: Walking survey of the school grounds and immediate surroundings, observing and recording human and physical features using simple tally charts and sketch maps.

name: The United Kingdom: Countries, Capitals and Seas
subject: Geography
curriculum_reference: NC KS1 Geography: 'name, locate and identify characteristics of the four countries and capital cities of the United Kingdom and its surrounding seas'
NC KS1 Geography: 'name and locate the world's seven continents and five oceans'
pedagogical_rationale: Locational knowledge of the UK is a statutory requirement that gives pupils their first detailed political geography, understanding that the United Kingdom is made up of four countries each with its own capital, surrounded by named seas. This concrete, mappable knowledge provides the spatial framework for all subsequent UK geography and connects to pupils' sense of national and regional identity.
common_pitfalls: Confusing England with the United Kingdom — deliberate, consistent use of precise terminology is essential
Teaching location names without using maps — names must be anchored to spatial positions
Treating this as rote memorisation rather than building genuine spatial understanding through repeated map use
cross_curricular_hooks: [History] The four countries of the UK and how they came to be united
[English] Reading stories set in different parts of the UK
[PSHE] Identity — which country do we live in? What does it mean to live in the UK?

name: World Continents and Oceans
subject: Geography
curriculum_reference: NC KS1 Geography: 'name and locate the world's seven continents and five oceans'
pedagogical_rationale: Naming and locating the seven continents and five oceans is a statutory KS1 requirement that builds the global spatial framework underpinning all subsequent geography. At this age, the emphasis is on building a mental map of the world at the broadest scale — recognising that the Earth is made up of large landmasses surrounded by named oceans — which gives children the vocabulary and spatial scaffolding to make sense of places they encounter in stories, news, and travel.
common_pitfalls: Treating this as a one-off labelling exercise rather than revisiting regularly to build secure recall
Confusing countries with continents (e.g. thinking Africa is a country) — use maps that show both
Only using flat maps — globes are essential for understanding the spherical Earth and relative sizes of continents
cross_curricular_hooks: [Science] Habitats in different continents; polar, desert, and tropical environments
[English] Stories and picture books set on different continents
[Music] Songs and rhymes for memorising continent and ocean names

name: Contrasting Non-European Locality Study
subject: Geography
curriculum_reference: NC KS1 Geography: 'a small area in a contrasting non-European country'
NC non-statutory guidance suggests examples such as a village in Kenya or a city in India
pedagogical_rationale: The contrasting locality study is a statutory requirement ensuring that pupils' earliest geographical experience extends beyond Europe, developing openness to diverse human geographies. Comparing a non-European locality with the local area teaches pupils that geography is about understanding similarities and differences between places, not just learning about 'exotic' locations. The school selects the specific locality, enabling choice of a place with meaningful connections to the school community.
common_pitfalls: Stereotyping the non-European locality — show daily life, schools, families, and modern infrastructure alongside differences
Focusing only on differences and not similarities — children in both places go to school, play, eat meals, and have families
Using outdated or poverty-focused imagery that creates deficit framing of the studied locality
cross_curricular_hooks: [English] Stories, picture books, and accounts from children in the contrasting locality
[Art] Art traditions and crafts from the contrasting locality
[PSHE] Similarities in daily life, empathy, and understanding diverse communities
[Science] Comparing weather and seasons between the two localities
sensitive_content_notes: Avoid 'charity tourism' framing — present the non-European locality with dignity and agency
Pupils of the heritage culture may have personal connections — create space for their knowledge and experience
map_types: simple plan map of contrasting locality

name: Hot and Cold Places: Seasonal and Daily Weather Patterns
subject: Geography
curriculum_reference: NC KS1 Geography: 'identify seasonal and daily weather patterns in the United Kingdom and the location of hot and cold areas of the world in relation to the Equator and the North and South Poles'
pedagogical_rationale: This statutory topic introduces the foundational relationship between location and climate: places near the Equator are generally hot, places near the Poles are generally cold, and the UK's temperate position produces distinct seasonal patterns. Observing daily and seasonal weather gives pupils direct, experiential evidence for geographical patterns, while the global dimension (hot and cold places) extends their mental map and connects to the Equator and Poles as key geographical concepts.
common_pitfalls: Confusing weather (what is happening today) with climate (what typically happens) — use the distinction explicitly and repeatedly
Teaching hot and cold places only from flat maps — a globe makes the Equator-Poles relationship much clearer
Presenting UK seasons as identical to all temperate places — note that seasons vary in different countries
cross_curricular_hooks: [Science] Seasonal changes, temperature measurement, and simple weather recording
[Maths] Recording weather data on simple charts and pictograms
[Art] Painting or drawing seasonal landscapes showing weather effects
[English] Descriptive writing about weather and seasons
map_types: world map showing Equator and Poles
data_sources: Photographs of hot and cold places
fieldwork_potential: Daily weather recording using simple instruments (thermometer, rain gauge) and observation charts over a half-term or term, building a class weather diary.
